ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, it is an interesting class. Normal amount of work but never felt overly taxing since the heaviest reading assignments were interesting, good reads.
definitely interesting material, and an interesting professor, but unless you're a "go with the flow" kind of student, the unstructured quality of the class might be a bit stressful

Definitely not. This was an awful, disorganized course. Assignments and weekly readings are given out by whim without significant thought. So forget having a syllabus or knowing what your week-to-week assignments will be. Seminar discussion is actually just two hours worth of rambling by Professor Weiss. The only perk is a light workload and easy grading. If you do decide to take this class as a gut (which I would NOT recommend), make sure to show up to class even though it feels pointless because Weiss will notice if you are absent.Class summary: random readings which you dont need to do until Weiss assigns a 4-6 page reading response (he assigned us 2 of these), a 30 minute presentation and a 12-80 page paper (yes, he actually said the responsible maximum for the final paper was 40 pages, single spaced with size 10.5 font)
